docs.lead_paragraph: Davis Love III is having his most consistent year in golf and one of the most emotional years of his life. After winning last weekend at the International, Love's fourth victory of the year, he denied rumors that he and his wife, Robin, were having marital difficulties.
docs.abstract: Golf Notebook discusses Davis Love III, who has four wins this season, despite year of turmoil that included suicide of brother-in-law and rumors that he was having marital problems; Thomas Bjorn, who lost British Open by one stroke, says he can bounce back for PGA Championship; Padraig Harrington could leave during PGA Championship to tend to pregnant wife, who is expecting child (M)
docs.snippet: Davis Love III is having his most consistent year in golf and one of the most emotional years of his life.     After winning last weekend at the International, Love's fourth victory of the year, he denied rumors that he and his wife, Robin, were...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many women of childbearing age who develop breast cancer worry that the stresses and hormonal changes of pregnancy will be dangerous. But a new study released yesterday in the journal Cancer found that becoming pregnant after a diagnosis does not raise the risk of dying. The study, led by Dr. Beth A. Mueller of the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle, said the issue was particularly pertinent because the number of women younger than 45 in whom breast cancer is discovered is increasing.
docs.abstract: Dr Beth A Mueller, Seattle's Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center doctor, leads study published in journal Cancer that shows becoming pregnant after breast cancer does not increase risk of dying, but rather increases chance of survival (S)
docs.snippet: Many women of childbearing age who develop breast cancer worry that the stresses and hormonal changes of pregnancy will be dangerous. But a new study released yesterday in the journal Cancer found that becoming pregnant after a diagnosis does not...

docs.lead_paragraph: The immersion course begins this winter. Jason Phillips's father, Clyde, will remove the leather covering from a tee ball and hit the rubber core off the streets of El Cajon, Calif. His son, wearing a first baseman's glove, will field the grounders off the asphalt, trying to keep the ball from going off a windshield. There, the transformation from catcher to first baseman will continue. ''We'll bang grounders just about every day,'' Clyde said by telephone. ''You hit it off the street and you have to have soft hands.''

headline.main: Mets' Phillips Plots His Path to First Base

docs.abstract: New York Mets catcher Jason Phillips will likely play first base as well next season, sharing duties with catcher Mike Piazza; photo (M)
